newsitem.title: USA: Key senator questions proposed new air standards.
newsitem.headline: Key senator questions proposed new air standards.

text.p: The chairman of the Senate Environment Committee Wednesday said he felt that proposed new air quality standards may be "too far-reaching."

"These are very complex and far-reaching proposals. After careful review, I am concerned they may be too far-reaching," Sen. John Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican, said in remarks prepared for a hearing on the proposed new air standards.
The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed setting tighter standards against soot and smog pollution.
"Frankly there is reason to be worried about the health of the Clean Air Act," Chafee said in a statement.

"Although EPA has done a good job on the acid rain and stratospheric protection provisions of the 1990 amendments, the ozone non-attainment programme has fallen far behind schedule. And these two new standards -- among the very largest regulations ever issued by EPA -- would be piled on top," Chafee said.
EPA Administrator Carol Browner was to testify at the hearing.
